question: Have any iGEM teams explored the use of E. coli or other microorganisms to develop innovative solutions for addressing environmental or health-related issues, such as reducing infections or promoting cleanliness?
reference_answer: Yes, the Eco-Life team has worked on a project that utilizes E. coli to address the Health-acquired Infection (HAI) problem through an atomizing diffusion method.
qa_context: Eco-Life is through the atomizing way to diffusion, it can help us fix the Health-acquired Infection (HAI) problem to get surrounding clean. We cooperated with dry lab and through small-scale experience to predict how the Eco-Life model works. The models are based on E.coli to discuss.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Eco-life, better life
qa_meta.Abstract: It is the Tunghai team`s first year to compete in the iGEM competition. Our team consists of 15 students working together in multidisciplinary teams to achieve our goal. Our members come from different backgrounds, with majors such as chemistry, chemical engineering, biology. However, we have something in common- we all are interested in synthetic biology and admire the concept of iGEM. At first, we were frustrated because of all of the details that need to be carefully accounted for, but after a lot of dedication, we observed that people are suffering HAI(Hospital Acquired Infection) these days. It can`t be denied how crucial the whole environment is to this human being. Therefore, we invented a new product and named it `EcoLife`, with its primary purpose being a air purifier. With this product, we are looking to provide a instrument alternative for those who pursue a healthy life.

answer:
Yes, based on the provided context, at least three iGEM teams (Tunghai TAPG, SIS Korea, and ITB Indonesia) have explored the use of microorganisms to address environmental or health-related issues.

Tunghai TAPG has worked on a project called "Eco-life, better life" that uses an atomizing way to diffusion, helping to fix the Health-acquired Infection (HAI) problem to keep the surrounding environment clean.

SIS Korea has developed a PET degradation system using genetically modified E-coli to break down microplastic particles, aiming to reduce plastic waste in the environment.

ITB Indonesia has designed Escherichia coli to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus, a pathogen that causes White Feces Disease in white shrimp, to help shrimp farmers detect the disease and take preventive measures.

qdrant_context.Abstract: In the past 65 years (1950 to 2015) only 7% of the 83 billion tons of plastic have been recycled, and 50% has been dumped into the environment. The effort of reducing plastic in the environment is being made by various fields, however due to the high cost of plastic treatment and its harmful side products a breakthrough is yet to be made. In this project we have established an improved PET degradation system. First, we utilized point mutations with enhanced PET degradation, and implemented a light inducible promoter to regulate the expression of PET-degrading enzymes more effectively. To increase the efficiency of the enzyme expression, we determined the best combination of some constitutive promoters and RBS. Not only that, we used a new signal peptideto increase the amount of secreted enzymes. From these results, we constructed a circulating incubator in which PET is degraded by transgenic E.coli.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: Development of PET Degradation Device Using Transgenic Escherichia Coli
qdrant_context.Wiki_content: The iGem project aims to find an effective way to decompose microplastic particles. The solution is to use genetically modified E-coli to produce the enzyme that can break down plastic. In sunlight the bacteria will become active to create the enzymes. With the flick of a light switch, one can control the production of PETase.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: shrimpal.id: Early Detection Tool for White Feces Disease in White Shrimp Ponds
qdrant_context.Wiki_content: We used 200 rpm and 37oC as a default condition for growing E.coli. Vibrio parahaemolyticus culture is grown in sea water LB broth media. We used Luria bertani media for all E.Coli cultivation.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate, PET, formed by condensation and polymerisation of terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG), is one of the most commonly used polyesters in the world. The degradation rate of PET is significantly slow which make them extremely persistent and hard to dispose. Although PETase can biologically degrade PET, the rate of enzymatic reaction is not suitable for usage in plastic waste treatment. Therefore, creating mutants which have a higher PET degradation activity may represent an effective and a long term solution of pollution from PET. After structural studies of PETase and its mutants, we hypothesized a more hydrophobic surface and narrower substrate binding site could lead to an increase in activity due to a better substrate interaction with PET. In our study, four single or double PETase mutants are produced and their PET degrading capacity are measured by enzyme activities for para-nitrophenol (pNP)-aliphatic esters.

The protein of all constructs except W159h/S245I and W159H/S214H were successfully expressed. For these two constructs, 0.0mM of IPTG is later found to be optimized for inducing the protein expression.

question: Have any iGEM teams worked on projects involving the engineering or modification of enzymes, such as PETase, to improve their performance or efficiency in degrading plastics?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not explicitly mention an iGEM team, it does describe a project that involves the modification of PETase to improve its performance, suggesting that the project itself may be an iGEM project or have similarities with one.
qa_context: A study of thermal decomposition and combustion products of disposable polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic. We aimed to enhance the performance of PETase by changing the properties of amino acid residues in the substrate binding site. We went through their experimental processes, looked at their rationale of mutant design, collected and analyze their results.

question: Have any iGEM teams explored the use of density-dependent gene regulation systems, such as quorum sensing, in their projects?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not explicitly mention quorum sensing, it does describe a density-dependent expression regulation system in V. parahaemolyticus, suggesting that the team may have been inspired by similar concepts.
qa_context: V.parahaemolyticus is naturally active in low cell density. But, when the cell density of bacteria is high, it will drive the expression regulation to repress the biomass production transcription factor and activate the toxicity. This unique cascade pathway can be adopted for our system circuit. To realize our system we use double plasmid system in Escherichia coli expression system.

We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. qa_meta.Project_Title: Anti-Aphid Angiosperm: use cotton chitinase gene to resist pest invasion
qa_meta.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

answer: No information in the context provided suggests that any iGEM team has developed mathematical models or computer simulations to describe the function and operation of BioBrick Parts and Devices. question: Have any iGEM teams explored the use of DNA nanostructures for targeted molecular interactions or sensing applications, such as detecting specific DNA strands or facilitating enzymatic reactions?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not mention a specific iGEM team, it describes a project that utilizes DNA nanostructures for targeted molecular interactions and sensing applications, suggesting that the team behind this context may have worked on such a project.
qa_context: DNA nano-structure is a structure made by several single-stranded DNAs. These DNAs are bound with each other according to the complementary base pairing principle. This formed DNA nano-Structure has the ability to bind with targeted DNA strand. In our assay, when target DNA is bound with the nano- structure, it could facilitate the formation of G-quadruplex in one end. This could facilitate peroxidation, so that peroxidase could be taken place.

qa_meta.Project_Title: NANO-TECHtrahedron: Using nano-tetrahedron to check for the probiotic concentration from food sample
qa_meta.Abstract: In iGEM 2017, our team successfully designed a DNA three dimensional nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker. To further prove the ability of the DNA nano-structure, this year we used four DNA strands to form a DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and the concentration of Lactobacillus instead of just a gene fragment of a bacterium. We successfully designed nano- triangular bipyramid applicable to the bacterium using Tiamat. We then successfully detect the presence and concentration of bacteria by measuring its peroxidase activity.

answer:
Yes, in the provided context, the team HK SKHLPSS has explored the use of DNA nanostructures for targeted molecular interactions and sensing applications. They used a DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of specific DNA strands (Lactobacillus) and to facilitate enzymatic reactions (peroxidase activity).

Additionally, the team also mentioned in their abstract that in iGEM 2017, they successfully designed a DNA three-dimensional nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker.

qa_meta.Project_Title: How I Met Diphto

qdrant_context.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: shrimpal.id: Early Detection Tool for White Feces Disease in White Shrimp Ponds

question: Have any iGEM teams explored the use of site-directed mutagenesis to enhance the activity of enzymes, such as PETase, by modifying amino acid residues in the substrate binding site?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not specifically mention an iGEM team, it does describe a mutation (W159H/S238F) designed by previous researchers to enhance PETase activity, suggesting that a similar approach could have been explored by an iGEM team.
qa_context: W159H/S238F was designed by previous researchers showed enhanced activity of PETase. The mutated amino acid residues located in the substrate binding site of subsite II which bound with MHET through hydrophobic interaction. W159H may have a synergistic effect with another amino residue changed when a double mutant is made.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Plasteriase: Mutating a Bacterial PET-degrading Enzyme
qa_meta.Abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate, PET, formed by condensation and polymerisation of terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG), is one of the most commonly used polyesters in the world. The degradation rate of PET is significantly slow which make them extremely persistent and hard to dispose. Although PETase can biologically degrade PET, the rate of enzymatic reaction is not suitable for usage in plastic waste treatment. Therefore, creating mutants which have a higher PET degradation activity may represent an effective and a long term solution of pollution from PET. After structural studies of PETase and its mutants, we hypothesized a more hydrophobic surface and narrower substrate binding site could lead to an increase in activity due to a better substrate interaction with PET. In our study, four single or double PETase mutants are produced and their PET degrading capacity are measured by enzyme activities for para-nitrophenol (pNP)-aliphatic esters.

answer: Based on the provided context, yes, iGEM teams (specifically HK GTC and SIS Korea) have explored the use of site-directed mutagenesis to enhance the activity of enzymes, such as PETase, by modifying amino acid residues in the substrate binding site. One specific example mentioned is the mutation W159H/S238F, which was designed by previous researchers and exhibited enhanced activity of PETase due to a synergistic effect and a more hydrophobic interaction with the substrate.

qdrant_context.Abstract: In the past 65 years (1950 to 2015) only 7% of the 83 billion tons of plastic have been recycled, and 50% has been dumped into the environment. The effort of reducing plastic in the environment is being made by various fields, however due to the high cost of plastic treatment and its harmful side products a breakthrough is yet to be made. In this project we have established an improved PET degradation system. First, we utilized point mutations with enhanced PET degradation, and implemented a light inducible promoter to regulate the expression of PET-degrading enzymes more effectively. To increase the efficiency of the enzyme expression, we determined the best combination of some constitutive promoters and RBS. Not only that, we used a new signal peptideto increase the amount of secreted enzymes. From these results, we constructed a circulating incubator in which PET is degraded by transgenic E.coli.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: Development of PET Degradation Device Using Transgenic Escherichia Coli
qdrant_context.Wiki_content: To overexpress the PET degrading enzymes in E.coli, we used two different expression systems. The first is the light inducible expression system, which was used by many iGem teams. The other option was the constitutive expression system which simply produced PETase nonstop with the use of a strong promoter.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

Complicated diagnostic method and ambiguous symptoms were the main obstacles in giving the optimal treatment, according to physicians. Therefore, a fast and convenient novel approach to enhance diagnostic precision is needed to mitigate diphtheria immediately. In regards, our team focuses on developing the diagnostic tool using K-12 chimeric bacteria and green fluorescent protein (GFP) to enable a rapid detection of Diphteria toxin upon binding. This novel technology is claimed to be fast, available, and easy-to-usewhich sets stepping stones regarding to the establishment of primary diagnostic tool for Diphtheria toxin worldwide. In addition, we aim to prevent future outbreaks using public education to enhance awareness regarding anti-hoax movements and introduce daily probiotic consumption to encounter low usages of probiotic in Indonesia

answer: Yes, the UI Indonesia team developed a diagnostic tool that utilizes a modified toxin, called diphtox, which is a modified version of the diphtheria toxin, and they also modified the salt concentration of their medium.

qdrant_context.Abstract: In the past 65 years (1950 to 2015) only 7% of the 83 billion tons of plastic have been recycled, and 50% has been dumped into the environment. The effort of reducing plastic in the environment is being made by various fields, however due to the high cost of plastic treatment and its harmful side products a breakthrough is yet to be made. In this project we have established an improved PET degradation system. First, we utilized point mutations with enhanced PET degradation, and implemented a light inducible promoter to regulate the expression of PET-degrading enzymes more effectively. To increase the efficiency of the enzyme expression, we determined the best combination of some constitutive promoters and RBS. Not only that, we used a new signal peptideto increase the amount of secreted enzymes. From these results, we constructed a circulating incubator in which PET is degraded by transgenic E.coli.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: Development of PET Degradation Device Using Transgenic Escherichia Coli
qdrant_context.Wiki_content: The iGem project aims to find an effective way to decompose microplastic particles. The solution is to use genetically modified E-coli to produce the enzyme that can break down plastic. In sunlight the bacteria will become active to create the enzymes. With the flick of a light switch, one can control the production of PETase.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Polyglu: Biosynthesis of γ-PGA with tailored D/L ratios
qa_meta.Abstract: -polyglutamic acid (-PGA) is an emerging biopolymer being widely used in cosmetics, biomedicine and othe fields. D-glutamate-rich -PGA is industrially produced by natural strain Bacillus species. D-glutamate degrades more slowly and L- glutamate has better biocompatibility. Therefore, -PGA with tailored L/D glutamate ratio is demanded for more diverse applications. By constructing the biobricks of -PGA synthase complex, g/L L-glutamate-rich -PGA was accumulated in Corynebacterium glutamicum. Using the mathematical models based on the fermentation profile, the fermentation was optimized, and 15 times more -PGA was produced than that before. By introducing glutamate racemase gene racE under different Ptac promoter mutants, the L-glutamic acid content in -PGA varies from % to %. Finally, we devoted to fine tune the D/L-monomer ratio using standarized RBS elements (RBS modified with bicistron design). Our project provides a method for customerized polymer biosynthesis with precisely controlled D/L ratio, and may expand to other biopolymer synthesis.
qa_meta.Nominations: "Best Education and  Public Engagement, Best Manufacturing Project"

answer:
Yes, from the provided context, Team JNU-China has conducted experiments using synthetic biology approaches. In their project "Polyglu: Biosynthesis of γ-PGA with tailored D/L ratios", they constructed biobricks of γ-PGA synthase complex, introduced glutamate racemase gene racE under different Ptac promoter mutants, and used standardized RBS elements to control the D/L-monomer ratio in Corynebacterium glutamicum.

They also optimized the fermentation process using mathematical models based on the fermentation profile, resulting in a 15 times increase in γ-PGA production.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate, PET, formed by condensation and polymerisation of terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG), is one of the most commonly used polyesters in the world. The degradation rate of PET is significantly slow which make them extremely persistent and hard to dispose. Although PETase can biologically degrade PET, the rate of enzymatic reaction is not suitable for usage in plastic waste treatment. Therefore, creating mutants which have a higher PET degradation activity may represent an effective and a long term solution of pollution from PET. After structural studies of PETase and its mutants, we hypothesized a more hydrophobic surface and narrower substrate binding site could lead to an increase in activity due to a better substrate interaction with PET. In our study, four single or double PETase mutants are produced and their PET degrading capacity are measured by enzyme activities for para-nitrophenol (pNP)-aliphatic esters.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: Plasteriase: Mutating a Bacterial PET-degrading Enzyme

qdrant_context.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.

qa_meta.Project_Title: How I Met Diphto
qa_meta.Abstract: Diphtheria, a lethal disease caused by the toxigenic strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, afflicted Indonesia in /10 mortality rates upon 593 national cases. Complicated diagnostic method and ambiguous symptoms were the main obstacles in giving the optimal treatment, according to physicians. Therefore, a fast and convenient novel approach to enhance diagnostic precision is needed to mitigate diphtheria immediately. In regards, our team focuses on developing the diagnostic tool using K-12 chimeric bacteria and green fluorescent protein (GFP) to enable a rapid detection of Diphteria toxin upon binding. This novel technology is claimed to be fast, available, and easy-to-usewhich sets stepping stones regarding to the establishment of primary diagnostic tool for Diphtheria toxin worldwide. In addition, we aim to prevent future outbreaks using public education to enhance awareness regarding anti-hoax movements and introduce daily probiotic consumption to encounter low usages of probiotic in Indonesia

answer: Yes, the UI Indonesia team used the NEBuilder HiFi DNA Assembly method in their project "How I Met Diphto". qa_meta.Project_Title: Anti-Aphid Angiosperm: use cotton chitinase gene to resist pest invasion
qa_meta.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

answer:
According to the provided context, Nanjing team used T4 DNA ligase for DNA ligation in their project. They employed the following conditions and buffers:

- 1 L of 10x T4 DNA ligase buffer
- L of T4 DNA ligase (provided by TAKARA)
- The system was kept under 16 for 3 hours to combine. 

No other information about T4 DNA ligase usage by other teams can be provided based on the given context.
